microstructure: in the low strain rate regime (up to 10 s -1 ) the deformation occurs mainly in evenly distributed bands, while in the dynamic regime the deformation is strongly localized in macroscopic shear bands accompanied by softening even after the onset of yielding. The Kernel Average Misorientation technique reveals a high level of lattice rotation within these bands that also carries intense shear. In addition, X-ray diffraction line profile analysis indicates that the sharp increase in the flow stress is mostly related to an increase of the dislocation density.
processing_method: arc-melted on a water-cooled copper plate under argon atmosphere, then high frequency induction melting in a sectorized cooled copper crucible under helium atmosphere, and finally casted by arc melting
evidence: The microstructure and the mechanical behavior of equimolar Ti 20 Hf 20 Zr 20 Ta 20 Nb 20 high-entropy alloy in a wide range of initial strain rates between 10 -3 s -1 and 3.4  10 3 s -1 were studied. A significant increment in the yield strength with increasing strain rate was observed. The yield strength at 3.4  10 3 s -1 was about 40% higher than that measured at 10 -3 s -1 . Analysis by electron backscatter diffraction shows that in the low strain rate regime (up to 10 s -1 ) the deformation occurs mainly in evenly distributed bands, while in the dynamic regime the deformation is strongly localized in macroscopic shear bands accompanied by softening even after the onset of yielding. The Kernel Average Misorientation technique reveals a high level of lattice rotation within these bands that also carries intense shear. In addition, X-ray diffraction line profile analysis indicates that the sharp increase in the flow stress is mostly related to an increase of the dislocation density.

microstructure: The material exhibits a random crystallographic texture and the grain size values are in the range of 10 -350 µm with an average value of ~200 µm. As it was revealed in a previous study, the size and morphology of grains as well as the chemical composition depend on the cooling rate during HEA processing. Indeed, it was shown that in the upper part of the ingot (lower cooling rate) the grains have a dendritic structure and the dendrite arms are mostly composed of Ta and Nb while micro-segregations consisting of Ti, Zr and Hf rich zones are found in the interdendritic zones.
evidence: The material exhibits a random crystallographic texture and the grain size values are in the range of 10 -350 µm with an average value of ~200 µm. As it was revealed in a previous study, the size and morphology of grains as well as the chemical composition depend on the cooling rate during HEA processing. Indeed, it was shown that in the upper part of the ingot (lower cooling rate) the grains have a dendritic structure and the dendrite arms are mostly composed of Ta and Nb while micro-segregations consisting of Ti, Zr and Hf rich zones are found in the interdendritic zones.

microstructure: mixture of distorted shear bands and twins
evidence: In the pioneering work by Senkov et al. [15] such features were identified as a mixture of distorted shear bands and twins. The authors estimated the threshold stress for twinning somewhere above 600 MPa in TiHfZrTaNb equimolar HEA, which was deformed by compression at room temperature in the quasi-static regime.

microstructure: EBSD and XRD investigations revealed strong strain localization in samples deformed at high strain rates, with dispersion of shear bands reduced with increasing strain rate. The density and thickness of bands decreased and increased, respectively. Individual grains are subdivided into elongated strips due to plastic deformation in slip planes, with slip traces mostly in bundles (slip bands) and interacting with grain boundaries or other slip traces, giving rise to wavy-like features. Large lattice distortion within the shear band and in the vicinity of the boundaries of the lenticular structures was observed.
processing_method: Postmortem microstructure investigations using EBSD and XRD
type_of_test: Compression behavior and strain rate effect
evidence: The effect of strain rate on the plastic behavior in equimolar Ti20Hf20Zr20Ta20Nb20 highentropy alloy was studied in the range of 10-3 s-1 -3.4  10 3 s-1. The difference in the mechanical performance at various strain rates was explained with the help of postmortem microstructure investigations using EBSD and XRD. EBSD investigations revealed strong strain localization in the samples deformed at high strain rates, which may cause the early softening during compression. It was found that the dispersion of shear bands was reduced with increasing strain rate, i.e. the density and the thickness of bands decreased and increased, respectively.
